article.headline: Coronavirus tally: Global cases of COVID-19 top 15.5 million,
article.body: The global tally for confirmed cases of the coronavirus that causes COVID-19 climbed above 15.5 million on Friday, according to data aggregated by Johns Hopkins University, and the death toll rose to 633,656. At least 8.9 million people have recovered. The U.S. case tally stood at 4.04 million after passing 4 million late Thursday, and the death toll rose to 144,305. The U.S. added more than 69,900 cases on Thursday, according to a New York Times tracker, that shows cases rising in 40 states over the last 14 days, led by Florida and Louisiana. That latter state's Gov. Jonathan Bel Edwards said its health care system is approaching a breaking point at a news conference. Brazil is second to the U.S. with 2.3 million cases and 84,082 deaths. India is third measured by cases at 1.3 million, followed by Russia with 799,499 and South Africa with 408,052. The U.K. has 298,731 cases and 45,639 fatalities, the highest in Europe and third highest in the world. China, where the illness was first reported late last year, has 86,045 cases and 4,649 fatalities.
